The BPS COVID-19 Team met yesterday to review a new dashboard of county and school district COVID case data which will be used to guide return-to-school decisions in Bismarck Public Schools. The dashboard includes county positive case rates and BPS student and staff COVID-related absences.

The 32-person BPS COVID Team, which includes staff, students and parents, meets weekly to study the impact that the start of school and BPS safety protocols have had on the spread of COVID-19.

From August 24 through September 6, Bismarck Public Schools brought athletes, staff and students back to school. The district’s overall 14-day positive and quarantine rate was 1.8% or 287 staff and students out of a total of 15,647 students and employees. Of those, 29 were positive student and staff cases; 258 were quarantined as being close contacts.

BPS is making this dashboard information available to the community at this link: https://bit.ly/2BDp1Ov

10 ways to prepare your child for school during the COVID pandemic:
• Have your child practice mask wearing and hand washing.
• Discourage mask shaming or bullying of any kind.
• Be a good role model by wearing your own mask in public.
• Have a quiet spot at home for learning with good internet.
• Teach your child to make a simple meal if you can’t be home to prepare one.
• Model being flexible with educational changes that may occur.
• Arrange for back-up childcare, if needed.
• Become familiar with the orange Blended Learning icon at https://www.bismarckschools.org/. Scroll through the Family Hub in the middle and the Student Hub on the left.
• If you can’t find a document or email you were sent, check the Fall Reentry Information icon at https://www.bismarckschools.org/ or email community_relations@bismarckschools.org.
• Student mental health is very important. If you need assistance, reach out to the Student Services staff at your child’s school.

Century High teacher Karri Landeis was surprised to learn she was chosen as the 2019-20 Chamber EDC Secondary Teacher of the Year for Bismarck. With no school last spring, the awards are being given this fall.

A group of her students wrote this when they nominated Landeis: “She is so tremendously dedicated to her work and cares about her students in a way we’ve never witnessed before. She makes learning enjoyable and makes it obvious every single day that we’re in class that she loves what she’s doing, and she loves us. If anybody deserves teacher of the year, it would be her.”

CHS principal Steve Madler said he knows students love Karri’s classroom because the bell will ring, and the kids are disappointed to move on to the next class; they want to stay!

Our Transportation Dept. held a Bus Roadeo driving competition with a timed obstacle course! Here are some details:
• In the serpentine, the bus must be driven in and out of three or more cones spaced closer together than the length of the bus.
• In the offset street, the bus must complete a simulated "lane change".
• In the rear duals clearance, the bus must carefully drive through a narrowing lane that is only three inches wider than the bus at its end.
• In the right hand turn, the bus must turn right while the near rear tire of the bus passes within six inches of the corner.
• In the customer stop, the bus must stop within inches of a simulated curb.
• In the reverse, the bus must reverse with the rear bumper coming within three feet of a cone behind the bus.
• In the left hand turn, the bus must turn left without hitting any cones placed close to the bus's path.
• In the judgment stop, which is the last obstacle in the course, the bus must stop less than six inches from a cone placed on the finish line.

The Bismarck School Board tonight voted to have all PreK-12 students start school August 31st in a Hybrid AB-AB day mode versus Face-to Face. The vote was 3 to 2.

Superintendent Jason Hornbacher made the recommendation to start the school year at Level 3 Hybrid. He cited the increasing number of COVID cases among BPS staff, in the city, and in Burleigh and Morton Counties. He said, “As a community, we need to do all we can to lower our numbers.”

Dr. Hornbacher feels if BPS opens face-to-face all week, the district won’t be able to sustain that model very long.

The updated Fall Reentry Plan is at https://www.bismarckschools.org/Page/3868 ; a new section on Decision Making Guidance has been added on pages 6-9. AB-AB calendars are being finalized and will be sent to BPS parents and staff hopefully tomorrow.

Each recipient will receive a $1,000 scholarship for college. Talia will attend the University of Montana to major in Political Science. Alyencia will attend Bismarck State College, then University of Mary to major in Nursing with an emphasis on Labor and Delivery. The other finalists were Justin Anderson, CHS, Taylor Johnson, Legacy High, and Chelsey Gehring, BHS. District AVID director Tana Sukauskas says, “Thank you for all of your hard work and commitment to success within the AVID program, your school, and community!”
